intro: Acacia cumanensis, commonly known as the Koa tree, is a flowering plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod fruits. The tree can grow up to 20 meters tall, with a straight trunk and a dense canopy of green foliage. Its flowers are small and yellow, often clustered in spherical inflorescences. Acacia cumanensis plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing food and shelter for various native species.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia cumanensis is primarily native to eastern Australia, including regions such as Queensland, New South Wales, and the Northern Territory. It is commonly found in tropical and subtropical areas, particularly in sandy soils along coastal and inland regions. This species thrives in open woodlands, grasslands, and heathlands, often in areas with a warm climate and well-drained soil. It is also occasionally found in parts of Southeast Asia, though its primary distribution remains in Australia. The plant is well adapted to fire-prone environments and plays an important role in local ecosystems.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia cumanensis was mainly introduced to areas with a warm, dry climate and well-drained soils, often found in coastal regions and inland dunes. It thrives in environments with moderate to high sunlight exposure and is commonly found in semi-arid and arid zones. This plant is often used for soil stabilization and as a source of timber and fuelwood.
